title.content: Managed Message Template Feature Improvement: Data Structure and Operational Visibility Enhancement

content.content: Managed messages are a template-based messaging feature that allows pre-registering message content as templates for easy sending later.
However, the existing implementation had limited functionality with poor scalability, and tracking sending status was difficult, making it hard to understand overall operational status.
To improve the feature's completeness and ensure operational stability, improving the data structure and establishing a standardized system to track sending status was necessary.
Modified message template data structure and improved pipeline to support more message types.
Automatically added standardized tags by utilizing request metadata during message sending.
Implemented dashboard to monitor sending status across various dimensions.

Improved the completeness of the managed message feature, and enhanced the data collection and analysis system to flow from metadata collection, tag storage, to visualization, securing operational visibility.

title.content: Semantic Caching Implementation: 25% Annual LLM Cost Reduction via Vector Search

content.content: We introduced a feature that uses LLM to recommend chat utterances for user experience.
However, frequent LLM calls were projected to cost approximately ₩900M annually.
We needed a way to reduce costs while maintaining a similar user experience.
As an intern at the time, I proactively proposed semantic caching techniques using real-time vector search.
Embedded real chat data and identified semantic conversation pattern clusters using PCA and HDBSCAN.
Used an add-on structure separated from the main server with embedded vector DB to prevent external traffic migration.
Load testing identified network I/O bottlenecks, addressed with lightweight multi-replica configuration for concurrency handling.
Semantic caching techniques were applied to 13 frequently appearing utterance meaning clusters in chat, enabling expected cost savings of 25%, over ₩230M annually in LLM call costs.

title.content: LangGraph-based Prompt Evaluation and Improvement Automation Agent PoC

content.content: When designing LLM services, it's important to write prompts optimized for the intended purpose.

However, evaluating prompt quality is difficult to quantify with consistent criteria due to natural language characteristics, resulting in time-consuming and costly trial-and-error-based gradual improvements.
An automation agent was needed to evaluate prompt quality with appropriate criteria across various situations and suggest improvements.
Connected three sub-graphs with LangGraph, receiving system prompts from users and designing an automated evaluation-improvement loop.
Planner graph dynamically extracts evaluation criteria from the input prompt and defines test scope by generating multiple personas and scenarios appropriate for the situation.
Actor graph simulates virtual requests in parallel based on generated personas and scenarios, generates responses, and automatically produces scores and feedback according to derived criteria.
Reflector graph determines improvement needs from evaluation results, rewrites prompts when necessary, and implements operational-level continuous improvement by incorporating human feedback loops.

Confirmed improvement effects through cross-validation between commercial LLM services and verified the feasibility of implementing a repeatable automation loop for evaluating and improving system prompts across various scenarios.
Also explored the possibility of expanding beyond one-time prompt usage into a prompt management infrastructure capable of continuous operation and maintenance.

title.content: SHAP-based Explainable Churn Probability Prediction Modeling by Chat Session PoC

content.content: Chat data is the area where the richest user interactions occur within the service, containing important insights to understand user experience and service issues.

However, chat data includes not only simple text but also time-series language and behavioral patterns, making it difficult for existing simple churn prediction models to clearly understand when and by what signals users churn.
Therefore, we needed a model that could precisely estimate churn probability by chat session and interpret the causes based on SHAP, and proceeded with a PoC to validate this.
Generated text embeddings with BERT/DistilBERT and extracted key language signals such as sentiment, politeness, and closing intent, structuring them as features.
Combined conversation metadata such as response time, message length, and reaction presence to build a feature engineering pipeline reflecting time-series flow.

Initially examined Transformer-based sequence encoders, but considering model size, inference speed, and operational difficulty, ultimately selected a LightGBM-based model to enable near real-time processing.
Used SHAP to analyze each feature's contribution, creating an interpretable structure for real-time monitoring of why the model predicted high churn probability at specific points.
Achieved rapid churn probability calculation at each chat progress point with a lightweight feature engineering + LightGBM-based model, enabling interpretable results in near real-time.
Based on this interpretation, explored the possibility of early detection of risk signals and establishing actionable intervention hypotheses.
